doc.previous: There is no known efficient formula for primes. For example, Mills' theorem and a theorem of Wright assert that there are real constants A>1 and Î¼ such that
doc.after: are prime for any natural number n. Here represents the floor function, i.e., largest integer not greater than the number in question. The latter formula can be shown using Bertrand's postulate (proven first by Chebyshev), which states that there always exists at least one prime number p with nÂ <Â pÂ <Â 2nÂ âÂ 2, for any natural numberÂ nÂ >Â 3. However, computing A or Î¼ requires the knowledge of infinitely many primes to begin with.[26] Another formula is based on Wilson's theorem and generates the number 2 many times and all other primes exactly once.
